												There's not much I can say about this game, since it's not just essentially, but LITERALLY a glorified flash-game, but I will make an effort at pointing out just how miserably bad it really is.First of all, the gameplay. In other words, none at all.Then there's the fact that despite the seemingly "culture neutral" nature of the name, you can ONLY play as the greeks. No foolin'. And unlike certain other greek-centric games, like Master of Olympus: Zeus, you don't get to explore greek myth, culture, legends or hell, even architecture!No, you pick between Spartans or Athenians, and then depending on which one you picked, you either prepare to go to war against literally every single foreign party you encounter, or ragequit to the main menu and restart as the Spartans after losing 80% of your population after the first raiding party when you're the Athenians.The insanely poor balance between the two barely even functionally different "factions" you can play as is laughable at best, and borderline depression-inducingly tragic at worst. Spartans get an invaluable military bonus, and the Athenians get just about bugger-it-up-the-ärse-all by comparison.Adding insult to insult and injury (that is, twice the insult to once the injury), the game has literally zero replayability. The game-world is STRICTLY pre-determined, down to what foreign parties you encounter, and their so-called "personalities".If you can't have the mind-implodingly vast random-factor complexity of the Civilization series as a whole boasts, then that's fine, but really, if you're going to make us PAY for your shïtty game, then at LEAST give us ANY kind of incentive to play it for more than an hour, and then thank GabeN for the refund policy on Steam, simply because we could play better games literally for free on any flash-games site that's ever existed since before the words "Call of Duty" was any more than an actual military term. 0/10

Posted: October 23, 2016
												Many people seem to be complaining about Marble Age being a "glorified Flash game". Well, it really quite literally is, considering that is the technology it uses (and you can find an earlier position in the series on those Flash games websites like Kongregate). But this isn't really a problem. In fact, The Binding of Isaac was a Flash game, too, and so what?No, the problem with this game lies in its mechanics. The simplicity, combined with cute graphics, pretty nice music, and semi-educational content would have actually made it a great little title, but Marble Age's convoluted and unpredictable gameplay is what ruins everything about it.To put it short, I have never seen a game this unbalanced. The progression of numbers (e.g. resources being required, your city's population etc.) is exponential, like in so many browser-based MMO strategies and other titles. But it is also so variable. Rather than being a smooth increase, it jumps all over the place. At one point you're suffocating, your city can't grow anymore, your tech research ground to a halt and you're passing turn after turn just to regain some military power. Then, you complete a goal and suddenly you have twice as much population as you had a moment ago, tons of new resources and several free technology levels. This pattern repeats from time to time, though you never really see it coming. It means that all the strategy goes to trash since the real way to progress is to fulfill whatever goals you have (or count on a lucky random event). What you're trying to do otherwise just doesn't matter.In fact, the whole game is built in such a way that there is an invisible path you're supposed to be following. You don't quite know where it is, so you'll always stumble a bit. Stray too far from it and you reach a place you can't get out of. Manage to stay on track and the whole game becomes really easy. This is actually quite extreme — you can essentially lose a game if you do one thing wrong in the early stages, for instance.(Here I'll note this isn't about following historical events or simply playing in an optimal way. The game is just constructed in such a manner that you have to make arbitrary decisions at right moments to be able to win.)To be fair, the game does try to rescue you if you stray, giving you gifts through random events, but this only exposes the gameplay's faults even more — if the only way for me to get back on track is to accept those gifts, which are just enormous, then this just shows how big the difference between the "right" play and the "wrong" play is, even though what is right and wrong is decided arbitrarily.It might seem like I'm complaining a lot about this subject but that really is something that ruins Marble Age for me. The game has more flaws than that (maybe I'll list some in the comments) but this is what makes it an unplayable rather than flawed title. Stay away from it unless you like gameplay that's about trying to guess what the developers intended for you to do at any particular stage.

												This game is charming and simple, but has a lot to offer beneath the surface and is surprisingly challenging.You start with just a few villagers and have to manage resources via sliders similar to Democracy, the first main goal is to keep a balanced economy capable of growth. As you play you'll research various upgrade paths that can unlock new buildings and improve your economy and army. Occasionally you'll be presented with a challenge, often the challenges will test your military and your economy, and often failing them still allows you to play albeit with penalties. As you play you get scouts that can explore the world, and settlers that can build extra colonies to provide bonuses to your capital. As you uncover other civilizations, you can make peace with them which allows for trade, form alliances with them which helps your army during military events, and eventually buy land from them which can increase your population capacity. Alternately, if your army is big enough and buffed enough and you have a few generals, you can conquer them.As you expand and unify Greece and Mesopotamia, you'll get to decide whether to form an empire or kingdom, and the world map will expand, what started centered around Greece becomes centered around all of western Europe, north Africa, and the middle east, and you encounter whole other civilizations. There are a variety of choices you get to make which can impact how you win, or lose, the game.Overall I'd say this is a great casual game, it's simple but endearing, and considering how cheap it is you could get a really good deal for your money.

												The gameplay wasn't bad at first. But when I tried to play as Sparta on meduim difficulty, I found the campaign forces you to play in a very precise way. AND be lucky with the RNG. Otherwise, you're going to lose every major challenge. Worse still, said required strategy makes a major shift roughly halfway through the campaign. It goes from forcing you to focus on military strength to forcing you to focus on economic strength. And this shift happens in a very short amount of time. It seems too short to make it feasible without plenty of special favors from the RNG.What would've made this better is if each major challenge had at least two different ways to beat them. That would've provided some flexibility in strategy.Oh, and did I mention you only get to play as either Athens or Sparta? It's not like a player can choose between many factions to fit their own playstyle. Granted, each of these two factions gets to choose between six perks at the start. But those perks make little difference. The campaign requirements are still too constricting and unfair.And while I'm griping about poor gameplay balance, I'll also mention the "overpopulation" mechanic in the late parts of the campaign. Even on easy mode, it becomes way too cumbersome. It feels like a hastily tacked-on way to increase end-game difficulty.Overall, not a good strategy game. Even for it's price range, I don't reccomend it, at least not without a major patch. But I doubt that will happen, considering the developer has already released another similar strategy game called Predynastic Egypt. Having only played that later game's demo, I can only hope it's gameplay is more flexible and better balanced than Marble Age.

Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam groupDisclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by Orlygift[www.orlygift.com]. Thank you for making this review possible!Few words about the gamePre-Civilization Marble Age is a quite complex but peaceful strategy game. You goal is to expand your territory, make alliances and just explore around your world. It's a really entertaining game, mostly thanks to being based on actual history, but still it's a nice way to spend free evening. It might not be the best strategy game around, especially with all those restrictions imposed by game as alot of potential development is wasted, yet it's one of the nicest I've personally playedAdvantages - Lovely cartoon(ish) graphics and practical, adjustable in-game UI - Surprisingly composite technologies tree that boosts up replay value of game a bit - Lets players refresh their knowledge about Greek history (which I like even more than my own) - Price is fair enough, especially when discounts are going on - "Hundreds" (In about 2.5h gameplay occured only few of those) historical events makes gameplay a bit more varied and interestingDisadvantages - Sounds are crappy and music doesn't fit in game - Too flash-like feel of a game - Short and limited in capabilities of itSummaryIt feels a bit like this game was left out too early, devs could give it a little more love, it deserves it. It also might be overwhelming for newcomers but after max. 1 hour, most of players should understand mechanics completely. Anyway, it's a pleasant game, with decent price tag, perfect to take a rest from bigger titles and just have fun expanding your little city with loads of random events on the way. Worth at least trying out!Personal score6.5 / 10If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

												TL;DR 5/10 A 1-track forced development of a civilization. Turn-based exponential clicker game.5/10?  That is not great. Why am I still recommending it?  Well--I enjoyed myself for what it was.As another reviewer warned before I played, this game plays like a clicker game, except turn-based.  Like all clicker games, the game goes through obscene levels of growth.  The result is that all of the action and growth that were done previously are quickly made irrelevant by the present state of growth.The first time I played, I layed out a carefully managed plan of my resources.  Timed events occurred expecting me to be at a certain level of the growth curve.  I failed most of the challenging event (invading civilizations) because I thought that I could play the game at my own pace.  Since I conceded each of these overly unfair wars, none of my people died, and I was allowed to continue with a 40% reduction rate of some resource.  So, I lasted through half the game until the Huns came in and utterly wiped me out even with conceding the war.  During this first playthrough at my own managed pace, the game would feel sorry for me at certain checkpoints.  At least 8 different times, the game simply said, "Your neighbors are progressing well; so you benefit from the collective prosperity. Here is a reward of XX population, XX money, XX culture, XX army."  Literally 4 huge boosts to my present inventories of resources to try to level the playing field for where the game expected me to be.Like other clicker games, your own army is irrelevant (when playing Athens, not Sparta). They participate, grow, and die in wars--but they are only meaningful as 5% of your army strength.  Your power comes from allying with neighbors and using their armies (20% of them) through treaty.  So, often, your army is your least important resource.  (The booster %bonuses to your army are very important, because they apply to your allied army)Since it is a clicker game but turn-based, growth is mandatory at a certain time pace.  You must grow your population as fast as possible.  You keep them fed, while boosting 4 other resources--Production, Culture, Gold, with Army mostly irrelevant.  The only way to grow those resources is by allocating your population to each of the various tasks, fully changable each turn.The second playthrough, I knew and could anticipate the non-random pre-timed events.  You shift your population into growing whichever resource is more important for the temporary challenge of the time.The Production resource will purchase booster Buildings for your civilation layed out in a progressive tree of choices (along with a maintence fee to manage from your Gold resource.)  Culture will purchase boosters from a progressive Technology tree.  Both trees are mostly an illusion of choice.  You cannot purchase anything other than 2 or 3 options, and you are forced to purchase the other options soon afterwards.  Especially in the Technology tree, you are not allowed to purchase a more important technology from a different branch of study--the game forces you to purchase the remaining options first from earlier availability.  So, your only choice is what exact order of purchasing do you make in a forced, linear consumption track.Many random events occur over the course of the 280-330 turn game.  "Here are some free armies."  "Here is some free culture."  "A city was poisoned; XX population die."  In a progressive game, these one time events are manageable and mostly shrugged off as a 1-3 turn delay.  However, I just hit mid-game the Starvation problem again.  You must have your farmers keep up with your growing population; yet because of the controlled expansion of farmers by the purchased Technology and Buildings, they can be maxed out.  So, my population got slightly ahead, with no ability to increase my farmers yet.  So, a few people die off and the population returns to an equilibrium of sustainability, right? WRONG !!  No joke--0.05% 100/200K of my people starved.  So, the game presents 3 punishments:  Give up some Culture growth for 10 turns, Spend an exhorbant amount of your Gold balance, OR murder 30% of your population.  OK--fine.  I took the Culture punishment.  However, next turn, the same problem is still there with no ability to rectify the food with increased farmers.  Again, 96/200K of my people die.  The game forces one of the remaining 2 choices of punishment.  So, after a few turns, the game forces you to murder 30% of your population because 0.05% were dying.This kind of absurdity is the norm for this flawed game.  Well, I suppose it is similar to real life.  In RL, you planned and managed your resources, got an education, worked hard at a vocation.  Guess what?  Today, a truck hit you OR you got fingernail cancer.  You may not be dead, but which crippling result will you now manage for the rest of your life?Grow your civilization along the path that the game expected, not much deviation is allowed.  Do this, and you will win the full achievements.  Almost.  Now do it one more time with the other Home city. (Athens or Sparta)FATAL FLAWS:#1 When conquering a city, you must beat them 3 times.  However, after each fight your armies lose an appropriate number in the fight.  However, for the target city, their armies magically respawn instantly.  Did they enlist more from the population?  -9M population, +16K army.#2 When trading, other bonuses stack onto your commodity trades.  Unfortunately, this means that it makes sense to ONLY BUY when trading.  The bonuses do not boost your return of gold when selling.Pay no more than $1.25 on sale for this.

												 A massive accomplishment in the gaming industry. There are many things I liked about this game. Here's a few strong points: Accurate mapping, large degrees of micromanagement and lots of real events happening at the real times gave a bolder illusion of reality. It made me feel like I was a real ruler. I loved the cartooney graphics; when the models are on this scale they look really good. I enjoyed the variety of boosts and debuffs that you could have. The call the legions was great if you were Sparta (lots of generals so you can really take advantage of the 100k more units) and it was funny how on Easy you could use call the legions to get equal troops to the Romans and then overthrow them. I couldn't find many bad things to say about this game, but they are big enough to make a point of: Real shame I couldn't play as a different city in Greece/Different country. Maybe open up a mod workshop so this is possible? The fact that I couldn't specify EXACTLY how many people I wanted doing a thing really annoyed me (Major OCD). The biggest nagging problem I found was that the Justinian Plague was REALLY confusing. For some reason sometimes things were unusable and sometimes they were and I think that because it's the least straightforward of the events it should have at least a LITTLE bit of prior instruction so you don't fail on your first time getting to that point in the game. All in all though, great game, I'd rate 9.2/10 in it's current state, and 9.8/10 if the issues are fixed.

The controls work fine so i don´t see why i should judge the game for it´s port.The gameplay is what really caught me. I enjoyed boardgames with this mechanic so i had no problem to love the polished version of it in this game.That said tho, beating the game is hard and will take multiple tries to finally do so. Luckily a decent variety of starting perks and two different factions give a nice replayability.Onto the bad parts then. This point would usually mean i don´t recommend the game as i hate the word: random. There are some random elements that might or might not happen on which your success is based. Now as i think no game should have randomness in it, why am i still recommending it?Becuase those things felt miner and are not what i took from the game.If you´re looking for a casual game to spend some hours on to finally beat and then set aside, i really had fun trying to figure out what comes next and how i could improve my play...

												This game looks and feels like a Flash game.  There is a definite beginning and end to the game, but it doesn't feel like a complete, compelling experience.  You can choose between two different civilizations to play as, but there is no real variety; it's the same thing each and every time.  Normally, there is a degree of randomness and variety in strategy games that doesn't seem to be present here.  While there are extra screens for managing things like diplomacy and science, turns play out on a screen that represents what your civilization is doing.  You have a certain population, and you use sliders to increase or decrease the number of people assigned to particular tasks.  Each task generates one more resources for your civilization, and new tasks are unlocked by building new "buildings".So, aside from dipping briefly into other screens when needed, all you do is adjust resource production on the main screen with slide controls, and click end turn.  I'm not at all opposed to games that use a minimal style--my favorite strategy game is MO1.  But something about it just doesn't work here and I can't recommend it at all.But, as with all games that have demos, I recommend you try it for yourself and see if you like it.  I ended up buying it because it was heavily discounted and I wanted to see if the game improved.  I don't hate it, but I don't particularly like it either.

												What is the best part of gaming?If you answered "moving sliders”, rejoice!Who needs all those AAA graphical or sound settings screen: with this nifty little game, I can move sliders around all-day long, without having to worry about ruining the planet too much as it won't be taxing my GPU or CPU in any way. 												This game is not all bad, but after 15h, I will abandon it for those reasons :- it's quite repetitive, you will always encounter the same events.- you earn "civilisation points" during your game, and you can spend those in future game... (who had this horrible idea ???).- the game is insanely hard, I do not think you can get good results without spending those "civilisation points".Combine those 3 reasons altogether, and you can understand my frustration.Appart that, if you like civ games, and just want to walk through the game twice (once with Athen, once with Sparta), I would still recomand it.
